data.title: VPA Senior Grant – Past Projects – Stanford Arts
data.text:
Micheal Brown (they/them/theirs) was born and raised in Houston, Texas. They graduated from Lamar High School before attending Stanford where they graduated with B.A. with Honors in African and African-American Studies and a minor in political science. Micheal is an avid reader, writer, music lover, and tennis fan! They also have a dog named Samantha Serena Brown. During their time at Stanford, Micheal lived in Ujamaa for three years and was involved with the Black House (BCSC), Lathrop Library, the ASSU, and the MLK, Jr., Research and Education Institute. Their Honors Thesis-- entitled From BET to Beyond: Exploring Black Family Culture and Black Media Politics-- is an interdisciplinary project that focuses on outlining various debates about the contemporary Black media ecology. Micheal has returned to their hometown to spend time with their family and in hopes of getting reacquainted with local activism and community organizing.

Lora Supandi (they/she) is a writer and filmmaker of Hakka-Indonesian descent. Through the diaristic and the imagined, they experiment with the possibilities of radical futurism, postcolonial landscapes, and unseen intimacies. Their work asks, “What does it means to dream during the apocalypse, and yet to still be pierced by cultural memory – the ephemeral, its decay, morphed by grief and history?”

Outside of their personal art practice, they teach film & cinema for a summer program at CalArts, assist with programs at the Institute for Diversity in the Arts, and work as an abolitionist with formerly incarcerated mothers. In the past, they have exhibited installation art in Berlin, collaborated with Asian poets in London, and participated in the Levinthal Tutorial in poetry with Wallace Stegner Fellow Jalen Eutsey.

Danika Lyle is a comedian, writer, and actor currently based in Los Angeles. They graduated from Stanford with a B.A. in Film and Media Studies in the African & African American Studies Concentration and an Honor in the Arts. At Stanford, they were a writer and performer in the Robber Barons sketch comedy team, a DEI Coordinator at Stanford Sierra Camp, a Head Writer for Gaieties, and a recipient of the Chappell Lougee grant for their web series concept Mixed Not Stirred, a comedy exploring the biracial experience of white-passing people in a post one-drop world. When they weren’t writing, they enjoyed being the Tuesday night baker at EBF and performing stand-up comedy at CoHo. After completing their honors capstone Cycle Breaks, a one-woman dramedy on the ethics of birth and breaking cycles of trauma, they decided to move to LA to pursue writing and live performance. Now, they work as an assistant in the Audio Department at United Talent Agency. Follow them on Twitter @Danika_Lyle.

Omar Howaida El-Sabrout (any pronouns, Comparative Literature with minor in Art History and Practice ‘22) is really excited about playing with dirt and fermenting! The prospect of making work about memory, identity, cultural heritage, community, brownness, queerness etc... etc... etc... is deeply thrilling to them and they feel immensely privileged to have been awarded this grant. They would love to chat with you, yes you dear reader, about any questions you may have relating to their process and their plans.

Angie Lee graduated from Stanford with a B.A. in English with creative writing emphasis and a minor in Human Biology. She wrote her honors thesis on representations of disability in Anthony Doerr’s “All the Light We Cannot See,” and her creative writing often explores her interdisciplinary interests in medicine and the humanities. Angie is a recipient of the Louis Sudler Prize in the Arts, Stanford’s Undergraduate Creative Nonfiction Prize, and the Chappell Lougee Scholarship. Her writing has appeared across campus as a part of the Medicine and the Muse Symposium, Stanford Arts Fair, Leland Quarterly, and Caesura. She was a panelist at the 2018 War, Literature and the Arts Conference, where she read from a work of short fiction. Angie served as a managing editor of The Stanford Daily, peer advisor for the English Department, and member of the class cabinet. In her free time, Angie likes to sing a cappella, eat spicy tuna rolls, and blog about how disabled people are, in fact, fully able.

Lorena Diosdado earned her B.A. in Art Practice with Honors and a minor in Education at Stanford University. Her work, through various media explores the multiple layers in which individuals from marginalized communities exist in the United States. Thrilled by others’ stories as well as her personal upbringing, she hopes to explore the complexities of marginalized individuals and communities surviving systemic oppression in the USA. Complicating conventional views of race & ethnicity, class, and gender her art focuses on untold, often sentimental, narratives, challenging art history and contributing to ongoing efforts by BIPOC artists to complicate popular understanding of their intersecting identities.

Robert Mungai is a film writer and director currently based in the Bay Area. He is working towards becoming a Television show runner in Hollywood working on a mix of prestige one hour dramas and half hour dark comedies. when he is not deconstructing the intricate worlds built by his favorite director, Christopher Nolan, he is spending time staring at blank pages, chasing his creative muses. Most recently, Robert interned for film producer Brad Krevoy at the Motion Picture Corporation of America. on campus, he has worked as Financial Officer for Cardinal Studios and co-president of the Sandbox 48-hour film festival.

Outside of film, Robert enjoys reading crime novels, accounts of the most daring art heists on the Vanity Fair archives and camping in and around the Bay Area.

Sounds and stories of growing up black in the Bay Area are blended with macro sociological commentary and introspection in the indie hip-hop of eli feier. feier seeks to ask, “who am I?” and "what world do I wish to see?" in an intimate take on conscious rap. feier believes that there are worlds inside each of our minds and that devotion to musical craft can build a place of convergence of said worlds, wherein we can find harmony and mutual understanding.

Natalie Johnson is a multimedia artist and aspiring novelist and filmmaker. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in African and African American Studies and was elected this year to Phi Beta Kappa. She also earned minors in German Studies and Creative Writing in the Fiction into Film track.

Engagement with the arts has been a cornerstone of Natalie’s Stanford experience. Her undergraduate coursework spanned Black diasporic artistic and political movements, African American literature, performance studies, film theory, as well as instruction in creative writing and film production. She is an alumna of the Stanford in New York program, where she interned at Firelight Films, and spent two quarters abroad with Stanford in Berlin and one quarter with Stanford in Cape Town. Natalie has also previously studied and interned in China and Taiwan. Her travels have significantly influenced her development as an artist, thinker, and activist.

On campus, Natalie acted in a devised production of The Mammaries of Tiresias (2017), directed by Davis Leonard (’19) and Gianna Clark (’19), and The Black Ratchet Imagination (2017), written and directed by Mysia Anderson (’17). She also participated in a 2020 Levinthal Tutorial in fiction with author and Wallace Stegner Fellow F. T. Kola. Natalie is also a 2019-2020 Student Fellow at the Institute for Diversity in the Arts, where she has been at work on an artistic and emotional exploration of her childhood home.

Natalie was born and raised in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. She is the youngest of six daughters.

Sara Carrillo is a senior studying Art History at Stanford University. She is interested in U.S. Latinx Art, particularly queer artists of color based in Los Angeles. Sara has worked at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art as a curatorial intern in Painting and Sculpture and hopes to continue to pursue curatorial work in the future. She is on the board of the Professional Arts Society of Stanford (PASS) and has worked as an editor of Untitled, Stanford’s only undergraduate art history journal. In Fall 2020, she will begin her graduate studies at the University of Texas, Austin.

Starr Jiang is a designer and director from the Bay Area. She received her B.S. in Computer Science at Stanford University.

At Stanford, Starr served as the Executive Producer of Asian American Theater Project, an Asian American activist theater company founded by David Henry Hwang in 1978. Past productions on which she has worked include Guards at the Taj, by Rajiv Joseph and The Wolves, by Sarah DeLappe.

Starr has also collaborated with JUST ART, an artist/activist collective based in Palo Alto. With the group, she co-produced Lighten Up, a comedy festival centered around colorism, and CENTRIFUGE, a three-part theater experience brings together stories of displaced individuals from Vietnam, Central America, and Palestine and Syria.

Outside of theater, Starr is interested in exploring the intersections of design, technology, and storytelling. She co-created the online explainer Brand Play, an interactive ad design interface that illustrates the gender biases behind advertising. Starr is also a poet and writer working to reimagine family narratives in a world without borders. She was a Levinthal scholar and worked with poet Safia Elhillo on her upcoming chapbook.

An avid believer in the power of education and mentorship, Starr teaches and organizes for Girls Teaching Girls to Code, which provides mentorship in digital design and engineering for high school girls. She has previously taught English and computer literacy at Center of Science and Technology in Cape Town and visual arts for elementary school students at Lord of the Light art studio.
